_prev_prog_3.Description: Dow Victoria Site Prevention Program Elements

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The Dow Victoria Plant adheres to Corporate policies, which could be summarized as follows:

- All Safety and Environmental incidents are preventable.

- Committed to Zero Incidents.

- All employees and contractors are responsible for their safety.



Corporate policies are embodied in the numerous SHE and Engineering Standards, which apply globally.  We have implemented a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as to protect the environment.  These programs include both internal Responsible Care  requirements and governmental requirements, such as the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) rule and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.



FACILITY DESCRIPTION



The Dow Victoria Site consists of 38 acres, located approximately 9 miles south of the city of Victoria, in a rural setting south of SH 185.  The plant functions as a "tenant" on the larger INVISTA Victoria Plant site.



The plant consists of one manufacturing process producing Ethylene Copolymers (low-density Polyethylene resins).  In the production of these products, the following regulated substances are used as raw materials (except for minor transfer of ethylene waste streams to another on-site company):

- Vinyl Acetate monomer (VA)

- Ethylene

- Propane

- Propylene



WORST-CASE TOXIC RELEASE SCENARIO



The worst-case release scenario for a toxic chemical is failure of a Vinyl Acetate Railcar during unloading, with no mitigation assumed.  This release has an off-site impact, as determined by the use of the "RMP Comp" software.  This release is unlikely due to operator attendance during unloading and the preventive maintenance program on the railcars and unloading facilities.



WORST-CASE FLAMMABLE RELEASE SCENARIO



T

he worst-case release scenario for a flammable chemical is a large hole in the Propane Storage Tank or associated piping, with no mitigation assumed.  This release, if ignited, would have an off-site industrial impact, but no impact on residential populations, as determined by the use of the "RMP Comp" software.  The ignition of this release is unlikely because the tank is located in a remote location versus normal ignition sources.



ALTERNATIVE TOXIC RELEASE SCENARIOS



Vinyl acetate monomer (VA) - A pipe leak in either the Vinyl Acetate railcar unloading, transfer piping or storage tank was assumed.  A release duration of 60 minutes was assumed.  This release has an off-site industrial impact, but no impact on residential populations, as determined by the use of the "RMP Comp" software.



ALTERNATIVE FLAMMABLE RELEASE SCENARIO



Propane - A pipe leak in the Propane transfer piping was assumed.  Because of the possibly remote location, a release duration of 60 minutes was assumed.  Since a release would vaporize quickly, no mitigation was assumed.  This release has an off-site industrial impact, but no impact on residential populations, as determined by the use of the "RMP Comp" software.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Dow Victoria Site follows the requirements of corporate standards for Process Safety Management.  These standards include the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.



Our Safety Programs include:



Designing for Safety ...

   - A documented process technology system covers hazards of materials, equipment design basis, and process design basis.

   - Extensive accident prevention and mitigation systems are strategically located.

   - Applicable codes and standards are met or exceeded.

   - Materials of construction are chosen to provide mechanical integrity.

   - Quality Assurance ensures fabrication in accordance with design specifications and proper assembly.

Maintaining our Plant ...

   - Maintenance personnel are trained and experienced.

   - Contractors are trained and qualified.

   - A work permit system controls hazards.



Operating Safety ...

   - Operators are trained and job qualified.

   - Technical resources are available and utilized as required.

   - Operators follow approved procedures.



Auditing our Operations ...

   - Routine safety inspections are conducted.

   - Corporate, independent and government audits and reviews are conducted.

   - Process Hazards Analyses are conducted.

   - Safety critical equipment is set up on a periodic inspection frequency to ensure ongoing mechanical integrity.

   - Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted prior to starting up any new or modified equipment.

   - Quality assurance of critical equipment ensures fabrication in accordance with design specifications.

   - All incidents are investigated and actions taken to prevent recurrence.



          SAFETY IS A JOB REQUIREMENT FOR ALL EMPLOYEES AND CONTRACTORS!



THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



No deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage has resulted from a release of any of the regulated chemicals (Vinyl Acetate monomer, Ethylene, Propane, or Propylene) in the past five years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Plant personnel are trained and equipped to respond to any releases of the regulated chemicals.  The program can be summarized as follows:



*Emergency Contacts...

   -Board room operators act as Emergency Coordinators and can be contacted at the main control room 361-572-1364. 



*  Training and Preparation ...

   - Plant personnel receive emergency response training.

   - Plant emergency responders are trained.

   - Emergency response plans are current.

   - Plant participates in emergency drills.

   - Critiques are held on drills and actual events.

   - Plant is

a member of the Victoria Local Emergency Planning Committee.



*  If a Major Release Occurs ...

   - Emergency alarm is sounded.

   - Plant Emergency Operating Center is activated.

   - Plant Incident Commander and emergency squad respond.

   - Community emergency responders are notified as appropriate.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



*  Continued focus on the "Committment to Zero" for injuries and incidents.
